QuestionTxt: As you may know, President (Barack) Obama has proposed building a missile defense system to protect Europe from a potential Iranian missile threat.  Do you support or oppose such a system?
SurveySponsor: German Marshall Fund of the US and the Compagnia di San Paolo, Italy, with additional support from the Luso-American Foundation, Portugal, Fundacion BBVA, Spain, and the Tipping Point Fdtn., Bulgaria.
StudyNote: Interviews were conducted in the US by Kaplan Market Research.  Parallel surveys were conducted in Great Britain, France, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, Portugal, Poland, Spain, Slovakia, Turkey, Bulgaria, and Romania.  All fieldwork was coordinated by TNS Opinion and Social Institutes.

QuestionTxt: The UN (United Nations) Security Council has demanded that Iran stop enriching uranium, but Iran has continued to do so.  Please indicate whether you would strongly support, somewhat support, somewhat oppose or strongly oppose the UN Security Council taking each of the following actions....Not pressure Iran to stop enriching uranium
SampleDesc: national adult including an oversample of 18-29 year olds
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by Gfk Knowledge Networks using its national panel which is randomly selected from the entire national population and subsequently provided Internet access, if needed.  There was an oversample of 175 adults age 18-29 interviewed.  Results were weighted to be representative of a national adult population.

QuestionTxt: And now imagine that all of these non-military options (offer economic incentives to Iran in exchange for giving up nuclear weapons/impose economic sanctions/provide support to opponents of the current government in Iran) have been tried and the only option left to prevent Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons is the use of military force.  In that case, should the United States take military action against Iran, or should it simply accept that Iran could acquire nuclear weapons?
QuestionNote: The 'United States' was replaced in the European Union with 'European Union,' Russia with 'Russia,' in Turkey with 'Turkey'.
SubPopulation: Asked of those who said the best option to prevent Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons is to offer economic incentives to Iran in exchange for giving up nuclear weapons/impose economic sanctions/provide support to opponents of the current government in Iran (62%)
SurveySponsor: German Marshall Fund of the US and the Compagnia di San Paolo, Italy, with additional support from other organizations shown below
StudyNote: Interviews were conducted in the US by TNS US and Universal Survey.  Parallel surveys were conducted in Great Britain, France, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, Portugal, Poland, Spain, Slovakia, Turkey, Bulgaria, Romania, Sweden, and Russia.  All fieldwork was coordinated by TNS Opinion and Social Institute.  Additional support was provided by the Luso-American Foundation, Portugal, Fundacion BBVA, Spain, Communitas Foundation, Bulgaria, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Sweden, and the Open Society Foundation, U.S.

RespTxt: Accept that Iran could acquire nuclear weapons
QuestionTxt: And now imagine that all of these non-military options (offer economic incentives to Iran in exchange for giving up nuclear weapons/impose economic sanctions/provide support to opponents of the current government in Iran) have been tried and the only option left to prevent Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons is the use of military force.  In that case, should the United States take military action against Iran, or should it simply accept that Iran could acquire nuclear weapons?
QuestionNote: The 'United States' was replaced in the European Union with 'European Union,' Russia with 'Russia,' in Turkey with 'Turkey'.
SubPopulation: Asked of those who said the best option to prevent Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons is to offer economic incentives to Iran in exchange for giving up nuclear weapons/impose economic sanctions/provide support to opponents of the current government in Iran (62%)
SurveySponsor: German Marshall Fund of the US and the Compagnia di San Paolo, Italy, with additional support from other organizations shown below
StudyNote: Interviews were conducted in the US by TNS US and Universal Survey.  Parallel surveys were conducted in Great Britain, France, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, Portugal, Poland, Spain, Slovakia, Turkey, Bulgaria, Romania, Sweden, and Russia.  All fieldwork was coordinated by TNS Opinion and Social Institute.  Additional support was provided by the Luso-American Foundation, Portugal, Fundacion BBVA, Spain, Communitas Foundation, Bulgaria, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Sweden, and the Open Society Foundation, U.S.

Based on what you know, do you support or oppose this agreement with Iran?
SourceDoc: United Technologies/National Journal Congressional Connection Poll
StudyNote: Interviews were conducted by landline and cell phones.

QuestionTxt: Some members of Congress in both parties say that the US should now pass legislation calling for further economic sanctions on Iran. Supporters say this will increase pressure on Iran to reach a final agreement limiting its nuclear program. Opponents of additional sanctions say it would disrupt and possibly kill the negotiations towards a permanent agreement. Do you think Congress should pass further sanctions on Iran, or not?
SourceDoc: United Technologies/National Journal Congressional Connection Poll
StudyNote: Interviews were conducted by landline and cell phones.

RespTxt: No, should not pass further sanctions

QuestionTxt: As you may know, negotiations are underway between Iran and a group of six other nations, including the US. The objective of the negotiations is to try to prevent Iran from developing a nuclear weapon. The proposed agreement attempts to achieve this by allowing inspections into Iran's nuclear sites in exchange for reducing certain economic sanctions that are currently in place. Do you support or oppose pursuing this agreement or do you not know enough to have an opinion?
StudyNote: The sample included 350 respondents who use a cell phone only and 37 reached on a cell phone but who also have a landline.

QuestionTxt: As you may know, the US and other countries have announced a deal to lift economic sanctions against Iran in exchange for Iran agreeing not to produce nuclear weapons. International inspectors would monitor Iran's facilities, and if Iran is caught breaking the agreement economic sanctions would be imposed again. Do you support or oppose this agreement? Do you feel that way strongly or somewhat?
StudyNote: The survey was produced for ABC News by Langer Research Associates. The survey was produced for The Washington Post by Capital Insight. Interviews were conducted by Abt-SRBI. The interviews included landline and cell-phone-only respondents.

StudyNote: The survey was produced for ABC News by Langer Research Associates. The survey was produced for The Washington Post by Capital Insight. Interviews were conducted by Abt-SRBI. The interviews included landline and cell-phone-only respondents.

QuestionTxt: Thinking about the kind of candidate the Republican Party should nominate for president next year (2016), would you be more likely or less likely to support a candidate for the Republican nomination who...wants to end the nuclear agreement with Iran, or is this not a major factor in your vote?
SubPopulation: Registered Republicans including leaners who are very/somewhat/not too likely to vote in the 2016 Republican primary or caucus in their state
SurveySponsor: Pew Research Center for the People & the Press
SourceDoc: Pew Research Center for the People & the Press Political Survey
StudyNote: 525 respondents were interviewed on a landline telephone, and 977 were interviewed on a cell phone, including 560 who had no landline telephone.
